questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for placental abruption?
questions.solution:
Nulliparity: This statement is false. Nulliparity (having never given birth before) is not typically considered a risk factor for placental abruption. In fact, multiparous women (those who have had previous pregnancies) may have a slightly higher risk of placental abruption compared to nulliparous women.

Option-wise explanation:

  • a. Non-vertex presentation: This statement is true. Non-vertex presentations (e.g., breech presentation) can increase the risk of placental abruption, as abnormal positioning may lead to increased mechanical stress on the placenta during labor.
  • c. Low BMI: This statement is true. A low body mass index (BMI) has been associated with an increased risk of placental abruption, potentially due to inadequate nutritional status or other related factors.
  • d. PROM (Premature Rupture of Membranes): This statement is true. PROM is associated with an increased risk of placental abruption, as it can lead to changes in the uterine environment and increased risk of infection, which may affect placental stability.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Risk factor for Placental abruption.

  • The most predictive risk is abruption in a previous pregnancy.
  • pre-eclampsia,
  • fetal growth restriction,
  • non-vertex presentations,
  • polyhydramnios,
  • advanced maternal age,
  • multiparity,
  • low body mass index (BMI),
  • pregnancy following assisted reproductive techniques,
  • intrauterine infection,
  • premature rupture of membranes,
  • abdominal trauma (both accidental and resulting from domestic violence),
  • smoking and drug misuse (cocaine and amphetamines) during pregnancy.

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 63, Antepartum Hemorrhage

questions.text: If the placenta is thought to be low-lying at routine fetal anomaly scan, a follow up ultrasound examination, including a TVS is recommended at what gestational age?
questions.solution:
A follow-up ultrasound at 32 weeks gestation is recommended to assess the position of the placenta. By this time, the majority of low-lying placentas that are not clinically significant may have migrated upward as the uterus grows.

Here's an option-wise explanation:

  • a. 26 weeks: This statement is not recommended. While a follow-up ultrasound could be done earlier, it is generally too soon after the initial scan to assess whether the placenta has moved away from the cervical os.
  • c. 34 weeks: This statement is not ideal. Although a scan at 34 weeks can still provide useful information, the recommended time for follow-up is generally at 32 weeks to allow for adequate monitoring before labor.
  • d. At the onset of labour: This statement is not the standard approach. While the position of the placenta can be assessed during labor, it is more effective to evaluate it at 32 weeks gestation to plan for delivery appropriately if the placenta remains low-lying.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • Routine sonography in the second trimester of pregnancy provides early identification of placenta previa.
  • It is important to realize that the earlier the diagnosis of placenta previa is, the more likely it is to resolve at delivery secondary to placental migration.
  • Nearly 90% of placentas identified as "low lying" will ultimately resolve by the third trimester.
  • Follow up sonogram is recommended at 32 weeks of gestation to look for persistent placenta previa.

OLD CLASSSIFICATION:

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 63, Antepartum Hemorrhage

choices.text: Admit for monitoring of vaginal bleed

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with significant vaginal bleeding. She is G3P2L2A0 at 37+3 weeks of gestation. Her dating is accurate. She has a history of the previous two Cesarean sections. Her vital signs pulse 106 bpm, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and blood pressure 124/78 mm Hg. A speculum examination demonstrates active bleeding coming from the cervical os. A bedside ultrasound shows a placenta previa. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this case?
questions.solution:
Proceed to Caesarean section: This is the most appropriate management. Given the patient has significant vaginal bleeding and a confirmed diagnosis of placenta previa, especially with a history of two prior Caesarean sections, immediate delivery via Caesarean section is indicated to ensure the safety of both the mother and the fetus

Here's an option-wise explanation:

  • b. Induction of labour: This option is not appropriate in this scenario. Inducing labor with a placenta previa could lead to severe hemorrhage and complications for both mother and baby.
  • c. Admit for monitoring of vaginal bleed: While monitoring is important, it is not sufficient ,given that significant bleeding and the presence of placenta previa. Immediate intervention is necessary.
  • d. Follow up after 48 hours: This is not advisable in this case. The presence of significant bleeding and the diagnosis of placenta previa require urgent management rather than delayed follow-up.

The correct answer is a. Proceed to Caesarean section, as this is the safest option for managing significant bleeding in the presence of placenta previa

Key TAKEAWAY- Placenta previa

  • ACOG guidelines recommend delivery via Caesarean section between 36-0/7 weeks and 37-6/7 weeks gestation.
  • Never discharge a bleeding placenta previa.
  • Placenta previa is an absolute contraindication to IOL.
  • Proceeding with a Caesarean section is the best resort in this case.

choices.text: It is seen in association with severe form of concealed abruptio placentae
The condition can only be diagnosed on laparotomy
The uterine muscles over the affected area are necrosed and there is infiltration of blood and fluid in between the muscle bundles

questions.text: A 28 year old G3P2L1D1 woman presents to the ER at 35 weeks gestation with pain abdomen & bleeding per vaginum. On obstetric examination, uterine contractions ++, FHS could not be heard. On P/S, bulging membranes seen. CTG shows late decelerations with occasional sinusoidal pattern. Due to non-reassuring fetal status, decision for LSCS is taken. On table, the following is seen. Which of the statements is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The myometrial hematoma rarely interferes with uterine contractions following delivery. Thus, the presence of Couvelaire uterus as observed during cesarean section is not an indication per se for hysterectomy

  • The above image shows COUVELAIRE UTERUS (uteroplacental apoplexy).
  • It is a pathological entity first described by Couvelaire and is met with in association with a severe form of concealed abruptio placentae.
  • There is massive intravasation of blood into the uterine musculature upto the serous coat.

Option-wise explanation:

  • It is seen in association with a severe form of concealed abruptio placentae: This statement is true. Couvelaire uterus occurs when there is significant bleeding into the myometrium, typically associated with severe placental abruption.
  • The condition can only be diagnosed on laparotomy: This statement is true. While imaging may suggest the condition, definitive diagnosis often requires surgical intervention (laparotomy) to directly visualize the uterus and the extent of hemorrhage.
  • The uterine muscles over the affected area are necrosed and there is infiltration of blood and fluid in between the muscle bundles: This statement is true. In Couvelaire uterus, there is infiltration of blood into the myometrium, leading to necrosis and compromised blood supply in the affected areas.

KEY TAKEAWAY: COUVELAIRE UTERUS

  • It is seen in association with a severe form of concealed abruptio placentae
  • Hysterectomy is not universally indicated for the Couvelaire uterus.
  • It can only be diagnosed on laparotomy .

questions.text: A 23 year old primigravida presents to LR at 36 weeks gestation with pain in abdomen & bleeding per vaginum. Uterus is tender to touch, FHS could not be localized & dark altered coloured blood clots are being expelled. USG shows retroplacental hematoma & intrauterine fetal death. What is the grade assigned to this placental abruption?
questions.solution:
This is because there is severe separation, significant bleeding, and the presence of fetal death.

Page grading of Abruptio placentae

Class 0: Asymptomatic

  • Discovery of a blood clot on the maternal side of a delivered placenta
  • Diagnosis is made retrospectively

Class 1: Mild

  • No sign of vaginal bleeding or a small amount of vaginal bleeding.
  • Slight uterine tenderness
  • Maternal blood pressure and heart rate WNL
  • No signs of fetal distress

Class 2: Moderate

  • No sign of vaginal bleeding to a moderate amount of vaginal bleeding
  • Significant uterine tenderness with tetanic contractions
  • Change in vital signs: maternal tachycardia, orthostatic changes in blood pressure.
  • Evidence of fetal distress
  • Clotting profile alteration: hypofibrinogenemia

Class 3: Severe

  • No sign of vaginal bleeding to heavy vaginal bleeding
  • Tetanic uterus/ board-like consistency on palpation
  • Maternal shock
  • Clotting profile alteration: hypofibrinogenemia and coagulopathy
  • Fetal death

KEY TAKEAWAY- Page grading is used for placental abruption based on severity.

choices.text: Bleeding from accessory lobe of placenta & Sheehan's syndrome

questions.text: A 26 year old G3P2L2 woman at 34 weeks' gestation, met a road traffic accident. She is rushed to the emergency department. She is awake & alert, conscious and complains of intense abdominal pain due to the impact. Her vitals are BP 140/100 mmHg, Pulse 120/min, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min. FHS absent. USG shows intrauterine fetal death. Physical examination reveals several bruises on limbs & abdomen. Uterine contractions ++. There is presence of blood in the vaginal vault. What is the most likely diagnosis & its subsequent complication?
questions.solution:
• This appears to be a case of abruptio placentae as there is history of high impact road traffic accidents with bruising on abdomen, strong uterine contractions with absent FHS.
  • Grade 3 placental abruption (with IUFD) is most likely.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Placenta previa & Hypovolemic shock

  • Explanation: Placenta previa typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding and a normally functioning fetal heart. In this case, the presence of abdominal pain and absent fetal heart sounds does not support this diagnosis. Hypovolemic shock could occur, but it is not directly linked to placenta previa in this context.

b. Vasa previa & renal failure

  • Explanation: Vasa previa involves fetal vessels running across the cervical os and is associated with bleeding during labor or rupture of membranes, not trauma. Renal failure is not a direct complication of vasa previa.

d. Bleeding from accessory lobe of placenta & Sheehan's syndrome

  • Explanation: Sheehan's syndrome is related to postpartum pituitary gland failure due to severe blood loss during or after delivery, and not relevant to this case where there is fetal demise before delivery.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Placental abruption extending more than 50% of the placenta is associated with a higher likelihood of fetal demise.
  • Although normally associated with painful vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester, placental abruption following a traumatic event can occur without significant vaginal bleeding or regular uterine contractions.
  • coagulopathy is a serious complication of placental abruption.
  • Major abruption should be regarded as an emergency, requiring multidisciplinary input from the obstetrician, anaesthetist and haematologist. A fulminant maternal DIC can occur within hours of a complete abruption. Therefore, delivery should be arranged, as it is the only means with which to halt the DIC. Replacement of blood and its components should begin before surgery.

questions.text: A 28 year old primigravida presents to LR at 35 weeks of gestation with 3 cm dilatation of cervix & minimal uterine contractions. On ARM(Artificial Rupture of Membranes) fresh bleeding is seen. CTG shows late decelerations. The woman is taken for emergency LSCS but the baby could not be saved. No abruption or placenta previa was noted. What is the most likely cause of this bleeding?
questions.solution:
Vasa previa occurs when fetal blood vessels run across the cervical os beneath the fetal membranes. If these vessels rupture during ARM, it can lead to significant fetal hemorrhage, which can explain the fresh bleeding and the late decelerations observed on CTG. This is the most likely cause of the bleeding in this case.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Bleeding from succenturiate lobe

  • Explanation: A succenturiate lobe is an additional lobe of placental tissue that can be present but typically does not cause bleeding unless it separates or if there are complications during delivery. In this scenario, the fresh bleeding on ARM and late decelerations indicate a more critical condition.

c. Battledore placenta

  • Explanation: Battledore placenta refers to a placenta with an abnormal insertion of the umbilical cord at the margin of the placenta. While it can cause complications, it is less likely to directly cause acute bleeding during labor or ARM.

d. Cervical polyp

  • Explanation: A cervical polyp could potentially cause bleeding, but it is usually associated with less severe bleeding and does not typically cause late decelerations in fetal heart rate patterns. Given the context of this case, it is unlikely to be the primary cause of the bleeding.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Vasa praevia carries a significant risk to the fetus. Unprotected fetal vessels are at risk of disruption with consequent fetal haemorrhage, when the fetal membranes are ruptured either spontaneously or artificially.
  • Therefore, vasa praevia often presents with fresh vaginal bleeding and fetal heart rate abnormalities at the time of membrane rupture.
  • Fetal demise can occur in the absence of prompt intervention and the mortality rate is around 60%.

questions.text: Two most important risk factors for Placenta Accreta Spectrum, are:
questions.solution:
This is the correct answer. Prior Caesarean delivery increases the likelihood of abnormal placentation due to scar tissue formation, while placenta previa (the placenta covering the cervix) can lead to abnormal attachment of the placenta to the uterine wall, increasing the risk of placenta accreta spectrum.

Optionwise explanation:

b. Advanced maternal age & multiparity

  • Explanation: While advanced maternal age and multiparity may have some association with placental complications, they are not the most significant risk factors for placenta accreta spectrum compared to previous uterine surgeries and placenta previa

c. Prior Caesarean delivery & abruptio placentae

  • Prior Caesarean delivery is a significant risk factor, but abruptio placentae is not directly linked to an increased risk of placenta accreta spectrum. Abruption is more related to placental detachment rather than abnormal placental adherence.

d. Previous uterine curettage & placenta previa

  • Explanation: Previous uterine curettage can be a risk factor, but it is not as strong as prior Caesarean delivery. While placenta previa is relevant, the combination of prior Caesarean delivery and placenta previa is more significant in predicting the risk of placenta accreta spectrum.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Risk factors for placenta accreta spectrum.

  • previous caesarean delivery(Most common).
  • Placenta previa (placenta previa, the risk of placenta accreta is 3%, 11%, 40%, 61%, and 67%, for the first, second, third, fourth, and fifth or more Caesarean, respectively)
  • Additional risk factors include advanced maternal age, multiparity, prior uterine surgeries or curettage, and Asherman syndrome

Reference: ACOG Obstetric Care Consensus Placenta Accreta Spectrum

questions.text: Unexplained elevation of which of the following biomarkers is associated with an increased risk of placenta accrete spectrum?
questions.solution:
Abnormal results of placental biomarkers increase the risk of placenta accreta spectrum.

For example, unexplained elevation in maternal serum alpha fetoprotein is associated with an increased risk of placenta accreta spectrum.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Inhibin A

  • Explanation: Inhibin A is primarily associated with Down syndrome screening and is not specifically linked to an increased risk of placenta accreta spectrum.

c. Unconjugated estriol

  • Explanation: Unconjugated estriol is mainly used in screening for chromosomal abnormalities and does not have a well-established link to placenta accreta spectrum.

d. Inhibin B

  • Explanation: Inhibin B is involved in the regulation of follicle-stimulating hormone and is used in screening for certain conditions but is not directly related to an increased risk of placenta accreta spectrum.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Elevated levels of MSAFP in the maternal serum have been associated with an increased risk of placenta accreta spectrum, as it may indicate placental abnormalities.

Reference: ACOG Obstetric Care Consensus Placenta Accreta Spectrum

questions.text: A 32-year-old G5P4L3D1 woman at 30 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with a complaint of vaginal bleeding for the past 4 hours. The bleeding is painless, mild, and unprovoked but continuous. She underwent two C-sections three & four years ago. Her vital signs show blood pressure 90/70 mm Hg, heart rate 112 bpm, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, and temperature 98.6 °F (37 °C). A speculum examination shows active bleeding. TVS shows low-lying placenta. Considering the diagnosis, a Caesarean section is planned. Which drugs need to be administered to ensure a good fetal outcome?
questions.solution:
This is the correct answer. Betamethasone is administered to promote fetal lung maturity, while magnesium sulfate is given for neuroprotection, particularly to reduce the risk of cerebral palsy in preterm infants. This combination is the best choice for ensuring a good fetal outcome before the planned Caesarean section

  • The clinical scenario is most consistent with placenta previa, where the placenta implants over the cervical os.
  • Painless vaginal bleeding during the second or third trimester of pregnancy is the usual presentation.

Optionwise explanation:

Dexamethasone and nifedipine

  • Explanation: Dexamethasone is a steroid that can be used to accelerate fetal lung maturity, but nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, is typically used for tocolysis rather than for fetal outcome enhancement. This combination does not fully address the needs of the fetus in this scenario.

Dexamethasone and terbutaline

  • Explanation: Dexamethasone is appropriate for lung maturity, while terbutaline is a tocolytic agent. However, using terbutaline might not be necessary if the delivery is planned soon, and dexamethasone alone is not sufficient for optimal fetal outcome in the context of preterm labor.

Betamethasone and atosiban

  • Explanation: Betamethasone is effective for fetal lung maturity and atosiban is used as a tocolytic agent. However, atosiban may not be needed if delivery is imminent, making this combination less ideal for this specific scenario.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Patients of placenta previa with excessive or continuous vaginal bleeding should be delivered via cesarean section regardless of gestational age.
  • The patient should receive magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection and steroids for fetal lung maturity once she is admitted.

choices.text: Deliver by caesarean section at 36 weeks

questions.text: A 24-year old G2P1L1 has vasa praevia at her 20 week scan which was confirmed by transvaginal scan. What would be her further management?
questions.solution:
15% of cases the vasa praevia can resolve with advanced gestation, hence imaging should be repeated in the third trimester to confirm persistence.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Admission to Hospital

  • Explanation: Immediate hospitalization is not necessary at this stage. While vasa previa is a serious condition, management typically involves close monitoring and planning for delivery rather than immediate admission.

b. MRI scans to confirm diagnosis

  • Explanation: MRI is not routinely used to confirm vasa previa. Transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred method for diagnosis and follow-up. MRI may provide additional information in complex cases, but it is not standard practice for straightforward vasa previa.

c. Deliver by caesarean section at 36 weeks

  • Explanation: While delivery by cesarean section is necessary to prevent complications associated with vasa previa, the timing of delivery is typically closer to 34-36 weeks, depending on clinical circumstances and fetal well-being. However, this option does not reflect the immediate next step in management after diagnosis.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • In cases of vasa previa diagnosed at 20 weeks, the standard management involves close monitoring, with a follow-up scan in the third trimester (usually around 28-32 weeks) to assess the position of the vessels and plan for delivery.
  • This allows for timely interventions and assessment of fetal growth and well-being.

Reference: Placenta praevia, placenta accreta and Vasa praevia: Diagnosis and Management

RCOG Green-top Guideline No. 27

questions.text: A 27-year-old lady primigravida has documented vasa praevia in her 32 week USG which was confirmed by transvaginal scan. She has not had any vaginal bleeding. At what gestation should she be delivered?
questions.solution:
In a woman with antenatally diagnosed vasa praevia delivery between 34 and 36 weeks of gestation balances the risk of premature rupture of membranes, and subsequent fetal haemorrhage and death versus the risks of prematurity.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Deliver immediately

  • Explanation: Immediate delivery is not warranted if there is no vaginal bleeding or signs of fetal distress. While vasa previa is a serious condition, management typically allows for some time to prepare for safe delivery, especially in the absence of complications.

b. 32-34 weeks

  • Explanation: Delivering between 32-34 weeks is generally not recommended as it may result in the delivery of a premature infant, which carries risks. The aim is to allow for further fetal development while managing the risk associated with vasa previa.

c. 34-36 weeks

  • Explanation: This is the correct answer. The recommended timing for delivery in cases of diagnosed vasa previa is typically between 34-36 weeks of gestation. This timing allows for fetal development while minimizing the risk of vessel rupture during labor.

d. 36-38 weeks

  • Explanation: While this option may seem reasonable for some pregnancies, it is generally not advised for vasa previa due to the increased risk of complications. Waiting until 36-38 weeks could expose the fetus to the risk of vessel rupture or fetal distress.

KEY TAKEAWAY -

  • The recommended timing for delivery in cases of diagnosed vasa previa is typically between 34-36 weeks of gestation
  • This timing allows for fetal development while minimizing the risk of vessel rupture during labor.

Reference: Placenta praevia, placenta accreta and Vasa praevia: Diagnosis and Management

RCOG Green-top Guideline No. 27

questions.text: A G3P2L2 woman with previous 2 Caesarean sections undergoes a routine USG at 32 weeks of gestation. It shows absence of normal retroplacental translucent zone. On colour Doppler, multiple irregular placental lacunae with turbulent flow are seen. Ideal time for delivery in this case would be:
questions.solution:
In the absence of risk factors for preterm delivery in women with placenta accreta spectrum, planned delivery at 35+0 to 36+6 weeks of gestation provides the best balance between fetal maturity and the risk of unscheduled delivery.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Immediately

  • Explanation: Immediate delivery is not necessary unless there are acute complications or maternal/fetal distress. This option would not be ideal as it may lead to premature delivery without adequate preparation for the infant.

b. 32-34 weeks

  • Explanation: Delivering at 32-34 weeks is generally too early for optimal fetal development, especially considering the risks associated with prematurity. While there is a concern for placenta accreta spectrum, this timing does not allow sufficient fetal growth.

d. 37-39 weeks

  • Explanation: While this option may seem reasonable, it is generally not advised for women with a diagnosed placenta accreta spectrum due to the increased risk of complications as the pregnancy continues. Delaying delivery until this range may increase the risk of complications related to the condition.

KEY TAKEAWAY -

  • In the absence of risk factors for preterm delivery, planned delivery at 35+0 to 36+6 weeks is generally recommended for women with placenta accreta spectrum.
  • This timing provides a good balance between fetal maturity and minimizing the risks associated with unscheduled delivery

Reference: Placenta praevia, placenta accreta and Vasa praevia: Diagnosis and Management

RCOG Green-top Guideline No. 27

questions.text: Which of the following causes of antepartum haemorrhage is associated with the highest risk of fetal exsanguination?
questions.solution:
This is the correct answer. In vasa previa, fetal blood vessels run across or near the internal cervical os, making them vulnerable to rupture during labor or membrane rupture. When these vessels tear, the fetus can rapidly lose a significant amount of blood, leading to fetal exsanguination

Optionwise explanation:

a. Abruptio placentae

  • Explanation: Abruptio placentae is a serious condition where the placenta detaches from the uterus prematurely, leading to maternal hemorrhage and possible fetal distress. However, the blood loss primarily affects the mother, not fetal exsanguination directly.

b. Placenta previa

  • Explanation: Placenta previa involves the placenta partially or completely covering the cervical os, leading to painless maternal bleeding. While it can lead to complications, it does not directly cause fetal exsanguination.

d. Bleeding from succenturiate lobe

  • Explanation: A succenturiate lobe involves an accessory placental lobe, and bleeding from this area usually affects the mother more than the fetus. The risk of fetal exsanguination is lower than with vasa previa.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • 1.Vasa praevia carries a significant risk to the fetus. Unprotected fetal vessels are at risk of disruption with consequent fetal haemorrhage, when the fetal membranes are ruptured either spontaneously or artificially
  • vasa previa often presents with fresh vaginal bleeding and fetal heart rate abnormalities at the time of membrane rupture.
  • 3.Fetal demise can occur in the absence of prompt intervention and the mortality rate is around 60%

questions.text: "Sentinel bleed" or "warning haemorrhage" may be seen with which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The only symptom of placenta previa is vaginal bleeding.
  • The classical features of bleeding in placenta previa are sudden onset, painless, apparently causeless and recurrent, often unprovoked.
  • In about 5% cases, it occurs for the first time during labor, especially in primigravidae.
  • In about one-third of cases, there is a history of "warning hemorrhage" or "sentinel bleed" which is usually slight.
  • The bleeding is unrelated to activity and often occurs during sleep and the patient becomes frightened on awakening to find herself in a pool of blood.
  • The bleeding is unassociated with pain unless labor starts simultaneously.

Optionwise explanation:

b. Abruptio placentae

  • Explanation: Abruptio placentae involves painful vaginal bleeding due to premature placental separation. It is a sudden, severe condition, and the term "sentinel bleed" is not typically associated with it.

c. Vasa previa

  • Explanation: Vasa previa is characterized by rupture of fetal blood vessels, often leading to catastrophic fetal hemorrhage. It does not typically present with a "warning hemorrhage" but rather with sudden, life-threatening bleeding.

d. Vulval varices

  • Explanation: Vulval varices are dilated veins in the vulvar region, and bleeding from them is usually not referred to as a "sentinel bleed."

KEY TAKEAWAY-

questions.text: Imperfect development of the Nitabuch's layer is considered to be the etiology of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The major clinical problem in PAS is placental failure to separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Placenta previa

  • Explanation: Placenta previa refers to the abnormal implantation of the placenta over or near the cervical os. It is not related to defects in the Nitabuch's layer.

b. Abruptio placentae

  • Explanation: Abruptio placentae involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, which is not linked to the Nitabuch's layer.

d. Vasa previa

  • Explanation: Vasa previa involves the passage of fetal blood vessels across the cervical os and is unrelated to the Nitabuch's layer.

Answer: c. Placenta accreta spectrum

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Nitabuch's layer is a fibrinoid layer that helps separate the placenta from the uterine wall during delivery.
  • Imperfect or absent development of this layer leads to abnormal placental attachment, resulting in placenta accreta spectrum, where the placenta invades too deeply into the uterine wall

Radiological findings for placenta accreta spectrum include:

  • Ultrasound
    • Placenta previa: Present in more than 80% of cases
    • Vascular lacunae: Multiple vascular structures in the placenta that can create a "moth-eaten" or "Swiss cheese" appearance
    • Loss of retroplacental clear space: The normal hypoechoic zone between the placenta and myometrium disappears
    • Decreased myometrial thickness: The anterior myometrial thickness is less than 1 mm
    • Color flow Doppler: Turbulent lacunar blood flow, increased subplacental vascularity, gaps in myometrial blood flow, and vessels bridging the placenta to the uterine margin
  • Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging
    • Uterine bulging
    • Heterogeneous placenta
    • Placental bands
    • Focal interruptions in the hypointense myometrial border

choices.text: ART and maternal smoking increase the risk of placenta praevia
Caesarean delivery is associated with an increased risk of placenta praevia in subsequent pregnancies.
A digital examination should be avoided to prevent massive haemorrhage

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding placenta previa, except:
questions.solution:
• TVS for the diagnosis of placenta praevia or a low-lying placenta is superior to transabdominal and transperineal approaches, and is safe.
  • A digital examination should be avoided to prevent massive hemorrhage.
  • If sonography is not readily available, diagnosis by digital forniceal/cervical examination is done in an operating room and with preparations in place for operative delivery. This is known as double set-up technique. Even the gentlest examination can cause torrential hemorrhage.

Optionwise explanation:

a. ART and maternal smoking increase the risk of placenta praevia

  • Explanation: Assisted reproductive technologies (ART) and maternal smoking are known risk factors for placenta previa.

b. Caesarean delivery is associated with an increased risk of placenta praevia in subsequent pregnancies.

  • Explanation: Previous caesarean sections increase the risk of placenta previa in future pregnancies due to potential scarring and abnormal placental attachment.

d. A digital examination should be avoided to prevent massive haemorrhage

  • Explanation: A digital examination should indeed be avoided in cases of placenta previa, as it can trigger massive hemorrhage.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

1. Caesarean delivery is associated with an increased risk of placenta previa in subsequent pregnancies. This risk rises as the number of prior caesarean sections increases.

2. ART and maternal smoking increase the risk of placenta praevia.

questions.text: A 32 year old multigravida G3P2L2 with previous 2 Caesarean section comes to ER as an unbooked pregnancy at 34 weeks gestation with complaint of vaginal bleeding. A bedside scan was done which shows the following image. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Ultrasound features of placenta accreta spectrum in second and third trimesters include visualization of irregular vascular sinuses with turbulent flow, abnormalities of the bladder wall on ultrasound inspection and, possibly, myometrial thickness of less than 1 mm.
  • Absence of the echo-lucent space between myometrium and the placenta is not a reliable sign.
  • Colour flow mapping is a useful test for the diagnosis.

Radiological findings for placenta accreta spectrum include:

  • Ultrasound
    • Placenta previa: Present in more than 80% of cases
    • Vascular lacunae: Multiple vascular structures in the placenta that can create a "moth-eaten" or "Swiss cheese" appearance
    • Loss of retroplacental clear space: The normal hypoechoic zone between the placenta and myometrium disappears
    • Decreased myometrial thickness: The anterior myometrial thickness is less than 1 mm
    • Color flow Doppler: Turbulent lacunar blood flow, increased subplacental vascularity, gaps in myometrial blood flow, and vessels bridging the placenta to the uterine margin
  • Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging
    • Uterine bulging
    • Heterogeneous placenta
    • Placental bands
    • Focal interruptions in the hypointense myometrial border

Other options:

  • Molar pregnancy (Option a) would show a "snowstorm" appearance on ultrasound and is unlikely at this gestational age.
  • Vasa previa (Option c) involves fetal vessels crossing the cervical os, leading to fetal blood loss, which is different from the findings here.
  • Lower segment uterine fibroid (Option d) may cause bleeding but would not present with turbulent sinuses or have the same risk profile as PAS in a woman with prior caesareans.

KEY TAKEAWAY -

  • Multigravida with a history of two previous Caesarean sections, which is a significant risk factor for Placenta Accreta Spectrum (PAS).
  • The clinical presentation of vaginal bleeding in the third trimester, along with turbulent sinuses seen on the bedside ultrasound, strongly suggests PAS

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with painful vaginal bleeding for the last 2 hours. She is a G5P4 at 32 weeks of gestation. Her history is significant for occasional cocaine use throughout the pregnancy. Vital signs are blood pressure 140/86 mmHg, heart rate 94 bpm, respiratory rate 14 breaths/min, and temperature 37 degree C (98.6 F). An abdominal ultrasound is requested. Cardiotocography (CTG) shows a baseline fetal heart rate of 142 bpm, reduced variability, and no decelerations. What is the most likely cause of bleeding in the patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with painful vaginal bleeding at 32 weeks of gestation, which is a hallmark symptom of placental abruption.
  • The history of cocaine use is a significant risk factor for placental abruption, as cocaine can cause vasoconstriction and increase the risk of premature placental separation.
  • CTG findings of reduced variability without decelerations suggest fetal distress, which is often seen in cases of placental abruption.
  • The absence of decelerations rules out vasa previa or uterine rupture, which would typically show more severe fetal heart abnormalities.

OPTION B: Placenta previa usually presents as bright red, painless bleeding from the vagina, most commonly in the third trimester of pregnancy.

OPTION C: Ruptured vasa previa will result in severe fetal distress and fetal exsanguination, leading to fetal death.

OPTION D: A ruptured uterus is associated with loss of uterine contractions, recession of the presenting part, and abnormal cardiotocography (CTG)

KEY TAKEAWAY

questions.text: A 31 year old G3P2L2 female at 37 weeks of gestation presents with painless vaginal bleeding for the last 2 hours. The bleeding is of moderate amount. She denies any similar episodes during this pregnancy, and she does not have any abdominal pain. Her obstetric history is positive for a previous caesarean section 3 years ago. A placenta previa was identified during the fetal anatomy scan. Her vitals are stable. Ultrasound scan shows a single viable fetus and an anterior placenta previa. A decision is made to proceed with another repeat lower-segment Caesarean section. During the procedure, the placenta does not detach despite attempts at manual removal. What is the recommended next step in management?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is a. Proceed with a hysterectomy.

Explanation:

  • The patient has a placenta previa with placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), as suggested by the inability to deach the placenta during the C-section.
  • Placenta accreta occurs when the placenta is abnormally adherent to the uterine wall, making manual removal difficult and increasing the risk of life-threatening hemorrhage.
  • In such cases, the standard management, especially when conservative measures fail, is to proceed with a hysterectomy to prevent excessive bleeding and save the mother's life.

Other options:

  • Methylergometrine (Option b) is used to control postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony but is not effective in cases of placenta accreta.
  • Misoprostol (Option c) and carboprost (Option d) are also used for uterine atony or incomplete placental separation, but they are not indicated in the management of placenta accreta spectrum, where surgical removal (hysterectomy) is required.

KEY TAKEAWAY - The standard management when conservative measures fail, is to proceed with a hysterectomy to prevent excessive bleeding and save the mother's life.
